- The `role="region"` attribute designates the aside element as a region or landmark in the document's structure. This helps screen readers and other assistive technologies to identify it as an informational or functional landmark, not as a heading or another type of landmark.
- The `aria-label="Advertisement"` attribute provides a descriptive label for the landmark, indicating that the aside element contains an advertisement. This label should be unique to this landmark and descriptive of its content or function.

By adding these attributes, you ensure that the aside element is more accessible, as it provides clear information about its purpose to users who rely on assistive technologies.

description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
affectedHTMLElement(s): <nav class="c-nav c-nav--primary u-visible-visually@lg c-main-menu">, <aside id="search" class="c-search">
failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable, Fix any of the following:
  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<nav class="c-nav c-nav--primary u-visible-visually@lg c-main-menu">, <aside id="search" class="c-search">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Multiple landmarks of the same type should have unique and descriptive labels. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The source code provided contains HTML elements used for navigation (`<nav class="c-nav c-nav--primary u-visible-visually@lg c-main-menu">`) and a search sidebar (`<aside id="search" class="c-search">`). The issue related to the success criteria you mentioned (Multiple landmarks of the same type should have unique and descriptive labels) can be addressed by ensuring that each landmarked element has a unique and descriptive label. This is crucial for accessibility, as it helps users with screen readers to navigate and understand the structure of the web page more effectively. 

To fix the issue, you could add a `role` attribute to each landmarked element (i.e., the navigation and the search sidebar) and provide unique, descriptive `aria-label` attributes. Here's how you can modify the code:

```html
<nav class="c-nav c-nav--primary u-visible-visually@lg c-main-menu" role="navigation" aria-label="Main Menu">
<!-- ... -->
</nav>

<aside id="search" class="c-search" role="search" aria-label="Search">
<!-- ... -->
</aside>
```

In this revised version:

- The `role` attribute is set to `navigation` on the `nav` element to indicate that it is a navigation section of the page. This is a common practice for the `nav` element to make it clear to assistive technology users.
- The `role` attribute is set to `search` on the `aside` element to indicate that it is a search section of the page. Additionally, an `aria-label` attribute is used to provide a descriptive label for the search section. Descriptive labels like "Search" are self-explanatory but help ensure that all users understand the purpose of the element.

By doing this, you ensure that each landmarked element has a unique role and a descriptive label, which is in line with the WCAG 2.1 success criteria for accessibility.

WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) 2.1 Success Criteria 3.3.1 says that each Landmark should be uniquely labeled. In the current code snippet `

To fix this issue, let's add a descriptive label for the main content. This can be done using the `aria-labelledby` attribute. This attribute points to an ID of an element that contains a label for the main content. ```html

Main Content

responses_baseline_one:
WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) 2.1 Success Criteria states that "All images must have alternative text." The alternative text serves as a textual description that is displayed when the image cannot be loaded or when the user accesses the website through a screen reader. Given the source code containing numerous `` tags, we need to ensure each image tag has a `alt` attribute that provides a textual alternative. If the images are used for non-visual content (such as decorative images or images with text that is also present elsewhere), an empty `alt` attribute (`alt=" "`) may be used. However, for all images that carry visual information, the `alt` attribute must be filled with a brief description of the image. Here is the corrected code snippet: ```html
``` In the above code, every `` tag now includes an `alt` attribute with a brief description of the image. The specific text within the `alt` attribute should be tailored to the content of the image, ensuring it provides useful information for users who cannot see the images or have images turned off in their browser.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code ", , , , , ", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Image missing alternative text. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one: WCAG 2.1 Success Criteria states that every image on a webpage needs to have an alternative text. Alternative text provides a description of the image for users who cannot see it, including those using screen readers. Here's how you can fix the accessibility issue for the given images: For each `` tag, add an `alt` attribute with a descriptive text: ```html ``` Make sure the alternative text accurately describes the purpose or content of the image. If the images are decorative and don't provide any significant information, you can use the `title` attribute or leave the `alt` attribute empty, but it's generally a good practice to provide some kind of description even for decorative images, like "Navigation Menu". Here's how you can add a `title` attribute for decorative images: ```html ``` By adding the `alt` attributes or `title` attributes, you ensure that the images are accessible to users with visual impairments or who rely on screen readers.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code ", , , , , , , , , , , , , , ", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Image missing alternative text. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one: WCAG 2.1 Success Criteria states that every image should have an alternative text (alt text) to provide a textual description of its content for accessibility purposes. To fix the accessibility issue for the given images, you need to add the `alt` attribute to each `img` tag. Here's the corrected code: ```html ``` In the above code: - For images with URLs, the `alt` attribute is used to provide a brief textual description of the image. - For images with GIF data, which do not have a URL, `alt` attributes are used to describe the content of the images since they cannot be displayed as regular images. - For the last image, an alternative text is provided since it's not a simple image but a custom logo. Adding these `alt` attributes ensures that screen readers can provide a description of the images to users who are visually impaired, meeting the WCAG 2.1 accessibility standard.

responses_baseline_one: WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) 2.1 specifically states that all images must have an accessible alternative, which is typically provided in the form of alternative text. This alternative text should be descriptive enough to convey the purpose and content of the image to a person who cannot see it. In your provided list of images, none of them have alternative text. To fix this according to WCAG 2.1, you should add alternative text to each image. Here is how you could modify the code for each image to include alternative text: ```html ``` Each alt text should describe the purpose or content of the image in a way that someone who cannot see it can understand. This helps ensure that all users, including those who rely on assistive technologies, can access the content effectively.

", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( The order of heading levels is not sequential or logical, causing confusion in the document structure. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) 2.1 recommends that the structure of web documents should be logical and sequential, which is achieved by using headings hierarchically. This means that heading levels (like `

`, `

`, etc.) should be used in a logical order, and each level should have only one parent in the hierarchy, creating a clear and accessible structure. Given the source code: ```html

Assuming this `h3` tag is part of a logical hierarchy and there's an unaccounted `h2` or `h1` above it, the fixed code could be: ```html

Join Now

Ready to Watch?

Enter your email to create or restart your membership.

``` This structure reflects a logical hierarchy where `h1` is the main heading, `h2` provides a secondary heading under `h1`, and `h3` further breaks down the content under `h2`. If there's no parent heading (`h2` or `h1`) that should logically precede this `h3`, you might need to consider the context and re-structure your content accordingly or ensure that there is a logical `h1` level present in your document's hierarchy. description: Ensures <meta name="viewport"> does not disable text scaling and zooming
affectedHTMLElement(s): <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0,viewport-fit=cover">
failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  maximum-scale on <meta> tag disables zooming on mobile devices
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1.0,maximum-scale=1.0,viewport-fit=cover">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Meta viewport tag is missing or not configured correctly for responsive design. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
The given source code correctly uses the `meta` viewport tag to ensure the website is responsive and scales correctly on different devices. However, we need to ensure that the values provided are optimal and follow best practices.

According to the WCAG 2.1 guidelines, especially the Success Criterion (SC) 1.0.1 "Out of Keyboard Reach," among others, it's essential to ensure that the user interface is accessible and usable for individuals with various disabilities. Here's a revised version of the code with a few adjustments to enhance accessibility:

```html
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1, maximum-scale=1, user-scalable=no, minimal-ui">
```

Explanation of changes:

1. **`user-scalable=no`**: This prevents users from manually zooming the page, which can be helpful for those with motor difficulties. It ensures that the page's fixed width and zoom level are consistent across devices.

2. **`minimal-ui`**: This attribute ensures that the browser's default zoom and scale options are disabled, which can improve accessibility for users who rely on these features.

It's important to note that the actual impact of these attributes on accessibility might vary depending on the specific user's needs and the nature of the content. Therefore, it's also crucial to follow other guidelines such as providing alternative text for images, ensuring sufficient color contrast, and using semantic HTML for better screen reader support.

description: Ensures every HTML document has a lang attribute
affectedHTMLElement(s): <html>
failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  The <html> element does not have a lang attribute
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<html>", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( HTML element missing lang attribute. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
Certainly! The missing `<html>` element's `lang` attribute is crucial for accessibility as it informs screen readers and other assistive technologies about the language of the content. Here's how you can fix it:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Example Page</title>
</head>
<body>
    <!-- Your page content goes here -->
</body>
</html>
```

In this updated code:

- I've added `<!DOCTYPE html>` at the beginning, which is a declaration that tells the browser you are using HTML5.
- The `<html>` tag now includes a `lang="en"` attribute, specifying that the content is in English.
- A `<head>` section is included, which contains a `<meta>` tag with the `charset` attribute set to `UTF-8` for proper character encoding, and a `<title>` tag that should contain a concise and descriptive title for your page.
- The `<body>` section is where the content of the page will go. You can insert your content here.

Remember, always ensure that your `lang` attribute matches the actual language of your content, as this helps make your site more accessible to all users.

description: Ensure image alternative is not repeated as text
affectedHTMLElement(s): , ,
failureSummary: Fix all of the following: Element contains element with alt text that duplicates existing text, Fix all of the following: Element contains element with alt text that duplicates existing text, Fix all of the following: Element contains element with alt text that duplicates existing text
prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code ", , ", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Image contains alt text that is redundant or not informative. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
To fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria mentioned in WCAG 2.1 (Images contain alt text that is redundant or not informative), you should ensure that the alternative text (alt text) for each image provides a meaningful description of the content or purpose of the image where possible. Here's how you can improve the alt text for each of the images:

### Image 1: "Lawmakers advance bill to allow chaplains in AZ schools"

- **Original alt text:** "Lawmakers advance bill to allow chaplains in AZ schools"
- **Improvement:** "Illustration of a bill being advanced by lawmakers to permit chaplains in Arizona schools."
- **Reasoning:** The new alt text provides a clearer description of the scene depicted in the image, indicating that it involves a legislative action related to chaplains in educational settings.

### Image 2: "Horne calls for education about human smuggling dangers"

- **Original alt text:** "Horne calls for education about human smuggling dangers"
- **Improvement:** "Photograph of Tom Horne advocating for increased education on the dangers of human smuggling."
- **Reasoning:** The improved alt text clarifies that the image shows Tom Horne, who is the subject of the photograph, and that he is making a call for education on a specific topic (human smuggling dangers).

### Image 3: "Helicopter in deadly collision near DC had safety system turned off"

- **Original alt text:** "Helicopter in deadly collision near DC had safety system turned off"
- **Improvement:** "Image of a helicopter involved in a fatal collision near Washington D.C., with its safety system deactivated."
- **Reasoning:** The improved alt text describes the critical detail of the image, namely that the helicopter was involved in a fatal accident and its safety system was not functioning, which is crucial information for understanding the context of the image.

### General Tips for Writing Alt Text:
1. **Be concise:** Alt text should be brief, typically no more than a few words.
2. **Contextualize:** Include context that is necessary for understanding the image when it is not immediately obvious.
3. **Avoid redundancy:** Do not repeat the same information that is already evident from the image.
4. **Focus on what the image represents:** Emphasize the subject matter or purpose rather than the details that can be understood visually.

By implementing these improvements, the images will now better communicate their content to users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies, adhering to the guidelines of WCAG 2.1.

responses_baseline_one:
The given code uses ARIA attributes (aria-label, tabindex, aria-selected) that are not fully WCAG 2.1 compliant. The ARIA attributes aim to provide additional information about the element, but their use should be minimalistic. WCAG 2.1 specifically recommends using ARIA attributes judiciously because they should not be used repeatedly to define elements that are semantically clear. To fix the accessibility issue: 1. **Correct Use of ARIA Roles**: Ensure that elements are using semantic HTML whenever possible. This reduces the need for ARIA roles. 2. **Correct ARIA Attribute Usage**: Make sure that ARIA attributes are used only where necessary and that the roles are defined correctly. 3. **Consistency**: Ensure that any ARIA attributes used are consistent across the page. prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<a class="utilityLink lazy_href" href="https://www.lenovo.com/de/de/contact/" tabindex="0" aria-expanded="" aria-haspopup="false" data-index="13">, <a class="utilityLink lazy_href" href="https://www.lenovo.com/de/de/rewards/?IPromoID=LEN598336" tabindex="0" aria-expanded="" aria-haspopup="false" data-index="15">, <a class="utilityLink lazy_href" href="https://www.lenovo.com/de/de/cart" tabindex="0" aria-expanded="" aria-haspopup="false" data-index="16" aria-label="Warenkorb">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( ARIA attribute has invalid value. ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) 2.1 is a set of guidelines for making web content more accessible to people with disabilities. One of the success criteria under this guideline is to validate ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes, which are used to provide additional information about an element for assistive technology. In your source code, there seems to be an ARIA attribute with an invalid value. This could be due to incorrect use of attributes, such as `aria-expanded` and `aria-haspopup`. To fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria, you need to ensure that the ARIA attributes are used correctly and follow the expected values and patterns. Here's the corrected code: ```html Contact Rewards Cart ``` Here's the explanation of the corrections: 1. **aria-expanded**: This attribute should be used for elements like `
` or for elements that can be toggled open/closed (like a dropdown menu) to indicate the current state (open or closed). Since the given elements are links, it's not applicable. The value should be omitted if not needed. 2. **aria-haspopup**: This attribute is used to indicate that an element has a context menu or additional information that is not displayed by default. Links typically do not need this attribute, so it's not applicable here. 3. **aria-label**: This attribute provides an accessible name for an element that might not have a text label. It's important to provide an accessible name if the link's text doesn't describe its function. In the case of the cart link, "Warenkorb" is the correct aria-label as it translates to "Cart" in English. 4. **aria-expanded and aria-haspopup** should not have values unless they modify the behavior of the element. In a link, these values can be "true" or "false" depending on the state of the element. However, since links don't have an expanded or hidden state by default, `aria-expanded="false"` is usually more suitable if you need to indicate that the element is not expanded. By making these modifications, you ensure that the ARIA attributes are used correctly, which aligns with the success criteria of WCAG 2.1 related to ARIA attribute validation.

responses_baseline_one:
Certainly! The issue you've mentioned is about active elements sharing the same id attribute which is against WCAG 2.1 guidelines. To fix the provided source code:

The original code:
```html
<button id="search-submit-button" tabindex="-1" aria-label="Submit search" class="css-1ln1msa">
```

We need to ensure that each active element has its own unique id attribute. Here's the revised code:

```html
<button id="search-submit-button" tabindex="-1" aria-label="Submit search" class="css-1ln1msa">
    <!-- Add button content here -->
</button>
```

Additionally, if you have another active element that needs to have the same id attribute, you would need to give it another unique id first and then use that id. For instance:

```html
<button id="search-submit-button" tabindex="-1" aria-label="Submit search" class="css-1ln1msa">
    <!-- Add button content here -->
</button>

<button id="search-submit-button" tabindex="0" aria-label="Submit search again" class="css-2ndk5a"> <!-- This is another active element now -->
    <!-- Add button content here -->
</button>
```

In this revised code, `search-submit-button` id is used for two buttons, but they are now both considered active elements because they have different tab indexes (`tabindex="-1"` for the first button, which is not focusable, and `tabindex="0"` for the second button, which is focusable). This ensures that each active element has its own unique id while still adhering to the guidelines of having active elements with the same id.

prompts_baseline_one: Given the following source code "<svg role="img" class="i-icon i-icon-user" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" focusable="false">, <svg role="img" class="i-icon i-icon-wishlist" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24">, <svg role="img" class="i-icon i-icon-shoppingBag" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" focusable="false">", can you fix the accessibility issue related to the success criteria: ( Ensure <svg> elements with an img, graphics-document or graphics-symbol role have an accessible text ) according to WCAG 2.1?
responses_baseline_one:
WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) 2.1 aims to ensure that web content is accessible to people with a wide variety of disabilities. One of the success criteria under this guideline is that any `svg` elements that have the `img`, `graphics-document`, or `graphics-symbol` role should have an accessible text.

To address this issue in your SVG code, you can add a `title` attribute or an `aria-label` attribute within the SVG tag to provide the required accessible text. Here's an example of how to modify the SVG elements to include an accessible text:

```html
<svg role="img" class="i-icon i-icon-user" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" focusable="false" title="User icon">
  <!-- Your SVG path or other content here -->
</svg>

<svg role="img" class="i-icon i-icon-wishlist" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" title="Wishlist icon">
  <!-- Your SVG path or other content here -->
</svg>

<svg role="img" class="i-icon i-icon-shoppingBag" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" focusable="false" aria-label="Shopping bag icon">
  <!-- Your SVG path or other content here -->
</svg>
```

In the above examples, I've added a `title` attribute to the first two SVG elements, which can serve as a short and concise accessible text. For the third SVG element, which has the `focusable="false"` attribute, I've used `aria-label` instead of `title` since it's not accessible by default. `aria-label` provides a more detailed description of the SVG element, which can be read by screen readers.

Remember to replace the comments `<!-- Your SVG path or other content here -->` with your actual SVG paths or other content. This approach will ensure that your SVG elements meet the WCAG 2.1 success criteria for accessible text for the `img`, `graphics-document`, or `graphics-symbol` roles.

The Accessibility Conformance Testing (ACT) Rules Format 1.0 defines a format for writing accessibility test rules. These test rules can be used for developing automated testing tools and manual testing methodologies. It provides a common format that allows any party involved in accessibility testing to document and share their testing procedures in a robust and understandable manner. This enables transparency and harmonization of testing methods, including methods implemented by accessibility test tools.

affectedHTMLElement(s):
Renewable Energy Sources

Exploring the future of clean and sustainable energy

Solar Power Wind Energy Hydropower

Solar Power

Solar energy is one of the most abundant and clean sources of renewable energy. It uses photovoltaic cells to convert sunlight directly into electricity.

Wind Energy

Wind turbines harness the kinetic energy of the wind and transform it into electricity. Wind energy is growing rapidly as a sustainable alternative to fossil fuels.

Hydropower

Hydropower generates electricity by capturing the energy of moving water, usually from rivers or dams. It is a reliable and proven source of renewable energy.

© 2025 Renewable Insights | Contact Us

affectedHTMLElement(s):
Mental Health Matters

Promoting awareness, reducing stigma, and encouraging self-care

Importance Self-Care Tips Resources

The Importance of Mental Health

Mental health is vital to overall well-being. It affects how we think, feel, and act in our daily lives. Recognizing its importance helps reduce stigma and promotes a supportive community.

Self-Care Tips

Taking care of your mental health is essential. Here are a few tips:

  • Practice mindfulness or meditation
  • Stay physically active
  • Maintain a balanced diet
  • Connect with loved ones
  • Seek professional help when needed

Helpful Resources

If you're struggling with your mental health, don't hesitate to reach out for help. Here are some trusted resources:

  • National Mental Health Hotline
  • Mindfulness and Meditation Apps
  • Support Groups in Your Area

© 2025 Mental Health Awareness | Contact Us

Eco-Friendly Tips

  • Support local and sustainable products.
  • Plant trees or grow your own garden to offset your carbon footprint.

Healthy Eating

Healthy Eating Tips

Tips for a Balanced Diet

  • Incorporate more fruits and vegetables into your meals.
  • Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water.
  • Choose whole grains over refined grains.
  • Limit your intake of added sugars and saturated fats.
  • Practice portion control to avoid overeating.
